text: We therefore investigated whether corticosteroids affect anti-CD3 / CD28 - stimulated nuclear import of <extra_id_0> GATA-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: Stimulation of cells with anti-CD3 / CD28 resulted in a rapid cytoplasmic / nuclear <extra_id_0> GATA-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> translocation ( Figure 1A ) , confirming our previous results [ 12 ] .

text: We also confirmed a clear separation of nuclear and cytosolic fractions as indicated by histone H1 and <extra_id_0> MEK-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> markers ( Figure 1B ) .

The potent topical corticosteroid FP caused sustained loss of nuclear <extra_id_0> GATA-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression and cytoplasmic retention of <extra_id_0> GATA-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> at concentrations ranging from 10-12 to 10-8 M , which cover the therapeutic range [ 37 ] .

text: This effect was concentration - and time - dependent , with a peak effect of 11.6-fold at 30 min at a concentration of 10-8 M ( Figure 1C ) and was associated with marked reductions in anti-CD3 / CD28 - stimulated <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA expression ( Figure 1D ) and a loss of <extra_id_0> GATA-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binding to the native <extra_id_0> IL-5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter ( Figure 1E ) .
